Chapter 1.1:1: Love justice, you rulers of the world. Set your minds sincerely on the Lord, and look for him with all honesty.

Chapter 1.1:2: Those who do not try to test him will find him; he will show himself to those who trust him.

Chapter 1.1:3: Dishonest thoughts separate people from God, and if we are foolish enough to test him, his power will put us to shame.

Chapter 1.1:4: Wisdom will never be at home with anyone who is deceitful or a slave of sin.

Chapter 1.1:5: Everyone who is holy has learned to stay away from deceitful people. He will not stay around when foolish thoughts are being expressed; he will not feel comfortable when injustice is done.

Chapter 1.1:6: Wisdom is a spirit that is friendly to people, but she will not forgive anyone who speaks against God, for God knows our feelings and thoughts, and hears our every word.

Chapter 1.1:7: Since the Lord's spirit fills the entire world, and holds everything in it together, she knows every word that people say.

Chapter 1.1:8: No one who speaks wickedly will escape notice; sooner or later he will receive just punishment.

Chapter 1.1:9: The intentions of ungodly people will be closely examined; their words will be reported to the Lord, and then they will get the punishment that their wickedness deserves.

Chapter 1.1:10: God will tolerate no challenge, and since he hears everything, you cannot hide your complaining from him.

Chapter 1.1:11: So be sure that you do not go around complaining—it does no good—and don't engage in bitter talk. The most secret things you say will have their consequences, and lying will destroy your soul.

Chapter 1.1:12: Do not bring on your own death by sinful actions.

Chapter 1.1:13: God did not invent death, and when living creatures die, it gives him no pleasure.

Chapter 1.1:14: He created everything so that it might continue to exist, and everything he created is wholesome and good. There is no deadly poison in them. No, death does not rule this world,

Chapter 1.1:15: for God's justice does not die.

Chapter 1.1:16: Ungodly people have brought death on themselves by the things they have said and done. They yearn for death as if it were a lover. They have gone into partnership with death, and it is just what they deserve.

Chapter 2.2:1: Wicked people are wrong when they say to themselves, Our life is short and full of sorrow, and when its end comes, there is no escape. No one has ever been known to come back from the world of the dead.

Chapter 2.2:2: We were born by chance, and after life is over, we will be as if we had never been born at all. Our breath is no more than a puff of smoke; our mind is nothing more than a spark thrown off by the beating of our heart.

Chapter 2.2:3: When that spark dies, our body will crumble into ashes, and our breath will become part of the empty air.

Chapter 2.2:4: In time, no one will remember anything we ever did, and even our names will be forgotten. Our lives will pass away like the traces of clouds and vanish like fog in the heat of the sun.

Chapter 2.2:5: Our time on earth is like a passing shadow. There is no escape from the day of our death; it is fixed, and no one can postpone it.

Chapter 2.2:6: The wicked say, Come on, then, let's enjoy the good things of life, and live in this world the way we did when we were young and free of care!

Chapter 2.2:7: Let's drink the most expensive wines and use the finest perfumes. Let's not miss a single flower in the springtime!

Chapter 2.2:8: Before the roses wither, let's pick them and wear them in our hair!

Chapter 2.2:9: Let's all join in and leave signs everywhere of our carefree revelry! Life owes us that much!

Chapter 2.2:10: We'll oppress the poor, even if they are righteous. We'll show no respect for widows or old people.

Chapter 2.2:11: We'll call ourselves right if we are strong enough to get what we want. No one ever got anywhere by being weak!

Chapter 2.2:12: Righteous people are nothing but a nuisance, so let's look for chances to get rid of them. They are against what we do; they accuse us of breaking the Law of Moses and violating the traditions of our ancestors.

Chapter 2.2:13: They claim to know God, and they call themselves the Lord's children.

Chapter 2.2:14: We can't stand the sight of people like that; what they are contradicts our whole way of thinking.

Chapter 2.2:15: They are not like other people; they have strange ways.

Chapter 2.2:16: They think that our moral standards are so corrupt that everything we do should be avoided. They boast of having God for their Father, and believe that when all is said and done, only the righteous will be happy.

Chapter 2.2:17: But we'll see if that's true! Let's see what will happen when it's time for them to die!

Chapter 2.2:18: If the righteous really are God's children, God will save them from their enemies.

Chapter 2.2:19: So let's put them to the test. We'll be cruel to them, and torment them; then we'll find out how calm and reasonable they are! We'll find out just how much they can stand!

Chapter 2.2:20: We'll condemn them to a shameful death. After all, they say that God will protect them.

Chapter 2.2:21: That is how evil people think, but they are wrong. They are blinded by their own wickedness.

Chapter 2.2:22: They have never known God's secrets, never hoped for the rewards of a holy and blameless life.

Chapter 2.2:23: When God created us, he did not intend for us to die; he made us like himself.

Chapter 2.2:24: It was the Devil's jealousy that brought death into the world, and those who belong to the Devil are the ones who will die.

Chapter 3.3:1: But righteous people are protected by God and will never suffer torment.

Chapter 3.3:2: It is a foolish mistake to think that righteous people die and that their death is a terrible evil.

Chapter 3.3:3: They leave us, but it is not a disaster. In fact, the righteous are at peace.

Chapter 3.3:4: It might appear that they have suffered punishment, but they have the confident hope of immortality.

Chapter 3.3:5: Their sufferings were minor compared with the blessings they will receive. God has tested them, like gold in a furnace, and found them worthy to be with him. He has accepted them, just as he accepts the sacrifices which his worshipers burn on the altar.

Chapter 3.3:6: Their sufferings were minor compared with the blessings they will receive. God has tested them, like gold in a furnace, and found them worthy to be with him. He has accepted them, just as he accepts the sacrifices which his worshipers burn on the altar.

Chapter 3.3:7: When God comes to reward the righteous, they will blaze out against the wicked like fire in dry straw.

Chapter 3.3:8: They will rule over nations and peoples, and the Lord will be their king forever.

Chapter 3.3:9: Those who have put their trust in God will come to understand the truth of his ways. Those who have been faithful will live with him in his love, for he is kind and merciful to the ones whom he has chosen.

Chapter 3.3:10: The ungodly, however, will get the punishment their wicked thoughts deserve, because they rebelled against the Lord and ignored what was right.

Chapter 3.3:11: A man who has no use for wisdom or education has a miserable life in store for him. He has nothing to hope for. His labors are useless, and he will never accomplish anything worthwhile.

Chapter 3.3:12: The woman he marries will turn out to be irresponsible, and his children will go wrong.

Chapter 3.3:13: All his descendants will be under a curse. On Judgment Day God will reward the woman who has never been able to have a child, provided she has not been guilty of adultery. Then she will be happy.

Chapter 3.3:14: On that day, even the man who has been castrated will be rewarded with happiness, if he has kept the Law and has not stored up resentment against the Lord. Because he has been faithful, he will receive a special reward more precious than having children: a place in the Lord's heavenly Temple.

Chapter 3.3:15: Honest deeds are like a tree that bears marvelous fruit. Wisdom is like a root that is alive and can always send up new shoots.

Chapter 3.3:16: But children born of adultery or of a forbidden union will die an early death.

Chapter 3.3:17: Yet even if they do live a long time, they will never amount to anything. They will not be respected in their old age,

Chapter 3.3:18: and if they die young, they will have no hope or comfort on Judgment Day.

Chapter 3.3:19: Children born of a forbidden union suffer a miserable fate.

Chapter 4.4:1: It is better to have virtue, even if it means having no children. Your virtue will be recognized by other people and by God, and you will be remembered for it forever.

Chapter 4.4:2: Virtue provides an example for people to follow; when it is not there, they miss it. It has always been the finest prize a person can win, and it always will be so. It is the noblest of all the good qualities a person can have.

Chapter 4.4:3: No matter how many children are born of a forbidden union, none of them will ever amount to anything. They are illegitimate; they can never lay a firm foundation for themselves, never take deep root.

Chapter 4.4:4: Like trees with shallow roots, they put out leaves for a while, but they sway in the wind, and storms uproot them.

Chapter 4.4:5: Their branches snap off before they mature; their fruit never ripens, and it is good for nothing.

Chapter 4.4:6: On Judgment Day children born of a forbidden union will testify to the sin of their parents and act as witnesses against them.

Chapter 4.4:7: Righteous people, however, will find rest, even if they die young.

Chapter 4.4:8: We honor old age, but not just because a person has lived a long time.

Chapter 4.4:9: Wisdom and righteousness are signs of the maturity that should come with old age.

Chapter 4.4:10: Once there was a man named Enoch who pleased God, and God loved him. While Enoch was still living among sinners, God took him away,

Chapter 4.4:11: so that evil and falsehood could not corrupt his mind and soul.

Chapter 4.4:12: We all know that people can be so fascinated by evil that they cannot recognize what is good even when they are looking right at it. Innocent people can be so corrupted with desire that they can think of nothing but what they want.

Chapter 4.4:13: This man Enoch achieved in a few years' time a perfection that other people could never attain in a complete lifetime.

Chapter 4.4:14: The Lord was pleased with Enoch's life and quickly took him out of this wicked world. People were aware of his departure but didn't understand. They never seemed to learn the lesson

Chapter 4.4:15: that God is kind and merciful to his own people; he protects those whom he has chosen.

Chapter 4.4:16: Even when righteous people are dead and gone, they put to shame the wicked people who live on after them. In their old age the wicked will be disgraced by young people who have already achieved perfection.

Chapter 4.4:17: The wise may die young, but the wicked will never understand that this is the Lord's way of taking them off to safety.

Chapter 4.4:18: They make light of a wise person's death, but the Lord will soon be laughing at them. When they die, they will not be given an honorable burial. Even the dead will hold them in scorn and disgust forever.

Chapter 4.4:19: God will throw them to the ground and make them speechless. Like buildings shaken from their foundations, they will be reduced to piles of ruins. They will be in torment. People will soon forget all about them.

Chapter 4.4:20: They will come in fear to the Judgment, where their sins will be counted; they will stand condemned by their own lawless actions.

Chapter 5.5:1: On that day someone righteous, full of confidence, will stand before those who oppressed him and made light of his labors.

Chapter 5.5:2: They will be amazed to see him safe and will tremble with terrible fear.

Chapter 5.5:3: Then they will regret what they did, and groaning in anguish they will say to each other:

Chapter 5.5:4: This is the one we made fun of. We thought he was a joke. What fools we were! We thought he was crazy to live the way he did, and when he died, we didn't honor him.

Chapter 5.5:5: And now here he is, one of God's own children, with a place of his own among God's people.

Chapter 5.5:6: We were the ones who wandered off the right road. We never lived in the light of righteousness; we never caught the first glimmer of its light.

Chapter 5.5:7: All our lives we wandered across unmarked deserts, instead of following the road which the Lord wanted us to travel. And this lawlessness led us to ruin.

Chapter 5.5:8: We were so proud of ourselves—we bragged about how rich we were—and now, what good has it done us?

Chapter 5.5:9: All those things are gone now; they have disappeared like a shadow, like something you hear and then forget.

Chapter 5.5:10: A ship sails across the waves of the ocean, but when it is gone, it leaves no trace. You cannot tell it was ever there.

Chapter 5.5:11: A bird flies through the air, but leaves no sign that it has been there. It speeds along, riding through the thin air by the force of its wings, leaving behind no trace of its passing.

Chapter 5.5:12: An arrow splits the air when it is shot at a target, but at once the air closes up behind it, and no one can tell where it passed.

Chapter 5.5:13: It is the same with us—we were born, and then we ceased to be. We left no sign of virtue behind us; we were destroyed by our wickedness.

Chapter 5.5:14: What hope do wicked people have? Only the hope of straw blown about in the wind, the hope of ocean foam that disappears in the storm, the hope of smoke in the breeze. Their hope lasts no longer than our memory of a guest who stays one day and leaves the next.

Chapter 5.5:15: But the righteous live on forever. The Lord will reward them; the Most High will protect them.

Chapter 5.5:16: He will give them royal splendor and a magnificent crown. He will shield them with his powerful arm.

Chapter 5.5:17: He will go out into battle determined to defeat his enemies, and use the creation itself as a weapon.

Chapter 5.5:18: Righteousness will be his armor, genuine justice will be his helmet,

Chapter 5.5:19: holiness will be his invincible shield.

Chapter 5.5:20: He will sharpen his stern anger into a sword, and the forces of nature will join him in battle against those who are foolish enough to oppose him.

Chapter 5.5:21: Bolts of lightning will strike right on target, as if the Lord had made a bow out of the clouds and was shooting arrows.

Chapter 5.5:22: Hailstones will beat down on his enemies with terrible force. The oceans and rivers will come rushing over them in a devastating flood.

Chapter 5.5:23: Great windstorms will blow them away like straw. Lawlessness will be the ruin of the whole world. Evil actions will cause governments to fall.

Chapter 6.6:1: So then, you kings, you rulers the world over, listen to what I say, and learn from it.

Chapter 6.6:2: You govern many lands and are proud that so many people are under your rule,

Chapter 6.6:3: but this authority has been given to you by the Lord Most High. He will examine what you have done and what you plan to do.

Chapter 6.6:4: You rule on behalf of God and his kingdom, and if you do not govern justly, if you do not uphold the law, if you do not live according to God's will,

Chapter 6.6:5: you will suffer sudden and terrible punishment. Judgment is especially severe on those in power.

Chapter 6.6:6: Common people may be mercifully forgiven for their wrongs, but those in power will face a severe judgment.

Chapter 6.6:7: The Lord of all is not afraid of anyone, no matter how great they are. He himself made everyone, great and common alike, and he provides for all equally,

Chapter 6.6:8: but he will judge the conduct of rulers more strictly.

Chapter 6.6:9: It is for you, mighty kings, that I write these words, so that you may know how to act wisely and avoid mistakes.

Chapter 6.6:10: These are holy matters, and if you treat them in a holy manner, you yourselves will be considered holy. If you have learned this lesson, you will be able to defend yourselves at the Judgment.

Chapter 6.6:11: So then, make my teaching your treasure and joy, and you will be well instructed.

Chapter 6.6:12: Wisdom shines bright and never grows dim; those who love her and look for her can easily find her.

Chapter 6.6:13: She is quick to make herself known to anyone who desires her.

Chapter 6.6:14: Get up early in the morning to find her, and you will have no problem; you will find her sitting at your door.

Chapter 6.6:15: To fasten your attention on Wisdom is to gain perfect understanding. If you look for her, you will soon find peace of mind,

Chapter 6.6:16: because she will be looking for those who are worthy of her, and she will find you wherever you are. She is kind and will be with you in your every thought.

Chapter 6.6:17: Wisdom begins when you sincerely want to learn. To desire Wisdom is to love her;

Chapter 6.6:18: to love her is to keep her laws; to keep her laws is to be certain of immortality;

Chapter 6.6:19: immortality will bring you close to God.

Chapter 6.6:20: This desire for Wisdom can prepare you to rule a kingdom.

Chapter 6.6:21: So then, you that rule the nations, if you value your thrones and symbols of authority, honor Wisdom so that you may rule forever.

Chapter 6.6:22: I will tell you what Wisdom is, and how she came to be. I will not keep anything secret. I will trace her history from the beginning and make knowledge of her open to all. I will not ignore any part of the truth.

Chapter 6.6:23: No jealous desire to guard my own knowledge will make me hold back anything. Wisdom has nothing in common with such an attitude.

Chapter 6.6:24: No indeed—the more wise people there are, the safer the world will be. A sensible king can be depended on to give his people this kind of security.

Chapter 6.6:25: So then, learn what I am about to teach you, and you will profit from it.

Chapter 7.7:1: Like every human being, I am mortal. I am a descendant of that first man, who was made from the soil. I was conceived from the sperm of a man, in the pleasure of intercourse. For nine months my flesh took shape in the blood of my mother's womb.

Chapter 7.7:3: When I was born, I came into the world like anyone else. I began to breathe the same air we all breathe; and like everyone else, the first sound I made was a cry.

Chapter 7.7:4: I was wrapped in cloths and cared for.

Chapter 7.7:5: No king ever began life differently.

Chapter 7.7:6: For all of us, there is one way into life, and there is one way out.

Chapter 7.7:7: Realizing that I was only human, I prayed and was given understanding. The spirit of Wisdom came to me.

Chapter 7.7:8: I regarded her more highly than any throne or crown. Wealth was nothing compared to her.

Chapter 7.7:9: Precious jewels could not equal her worth; beside Wisdom all the gold in the world is a handful of sand, and silver is nothing more than clay.

Chapter 7.7:10: I valued her more than health and good looks. Hers is a brightness that never grows dim, and I preferred it to any other light.

Chapter 7.7:11: When Wisdom came to me, all good things came with her. She brought me untold riches.

Chapter 7.7:12: I was happy with them all, because Wisdom had brought them to me. I had not realized before that she was the source of all these things.

Chapter 7.7:13: I was sincere in learning from her, and now I am glad to share what I learned.

Chapter 7.7:14: No one can ever exhaust the treasures of Wisdom. Use those treasures and you are God's friends; he approves of what you learn from her.

Chapter 7.7:15: I pray to God that my thoughts may be worthy of what I have learned, and that I may speak according to his will. He is Wisdom's guide; he gives correction to those who are wise.

Chapter 7.7:16: We are under his power and authority—we ourselves, our words, all our understanding and skills.

Chapter 7.7:17: It is he who gave me true knowledge of the forces of nature: what the world is made of; how the elements behave;

Chapter 7.7:18: how the calendar is determined by the movements of the sun, the changing seasons,

Chapter 7.7:19: the constellations, and the cycles of years.

Chapter 7.7:20: He has taught me about the nature of living creatures, the behavior of wild animals, the force of the winds, the reasoning powers of human beings, the different kinds of plants, and the use of their roots as medicine.

Chapter 7.7:21: I learned things that were well known and things that had never been known before,

Chapter 7.7:22: because Wisdom, who gave shape to everything that exists, was my teacher. The spirit of Wisdom is intelligent and holy. It is of one nature but reveals itself in many ways. It is not made of any material substance, and it moves about freely. It is clear, clean, and confident; it cannot be harmed. It loves what is good. It is sharp and unconquerable,

Chapter 7.7:23: kind, and a friend of humanity. It is dependable and sure, and has no worries. It has power over everything, and sees everything. It penetrates every spirit that is intelligent and pure, no matter how delicate its substance may be.

Chapter 7.7:24: Wisdom moves more easily than motion itself; she is so pure that she penetrates everything.

Chapter 7.7:25: She is a breath of God's power—a pure and radiant stream of glory from the Almighty. Nothing that is defiled can ever steal its way into Wisdom.

Chapter 7.7:26: She is a reflection of eternal light, a perfect mirror of God's activity and goodness.

Chapter 7.7:27: Even though Wisdom acts alone, she can do anything. She makes everything new, although she herself never changes. From generation to generation she enters the souls of holy people, and makes them God's friends and prophets.

Chapter 7.7:28: There is nothing that God loves more than people who are at home with Wisdom.

Chapter 7.7:29: Wisdom is more beautiful than the sun and all the constellations. She is better than light itself,

Chapter 7.7:30: because night always follows day, but evil never overcomes Wisdom.

Chapter 8.8:1: Her great power reaches into every part of the world, and she sets everything in useful order.

Chapter 8.8:2: Wisdom has been my love. I courted her when I was young and wanted to make her my bride. I fell in love with her beauty.

Chapter 8.8:3: She glorifies her noble origin by living with God, the Lord of all, who loves her.

Chapter 8.8:4: She is familiar with God's mysteries and helps determine his course of action.

Chapter 8.8:5: Is it good to have riches in this life? Nothing can make you richer than Wisdom, who makes everything function.

Chapter 8.8:6: Is knowledge a useful thing to have? Nothing is better than Wisdom, who has given shape to everything that exists.

Chapter 8.8:7: Do you love justice? All the virtues are the result of Wisdom's work: justice and courage, self-control and understanding. Life can offer us nothing more valuable than these.

Chapter 8.8:8: Do you want to have wide experience? Wisdom knows the lessons of history and can anticipate the future. She knows how to interpret what people say and how to solve problems. She knows the miracles that God will perform, and how the movements of history will develop.

Chapter 8.8:9: So I decided to take Wisdom home to live with me, because I knew that she would give me good advice and encourage me in times of trouble and grief.

Chapter 8.8:10: I thought to myself, Because of her I will be honored wherever people come together. The old men will respect me, even though I am young.

Chapter 8.8:11: They will find that my opinions show deep insight, and those in power will admire me.

Chapter 8.8:12: When I am silent, they will wait for me to speak, and when I speak, they will pay attention. Even when I speak at length, they will listen with concentration.

Chapter 8.8:13: Because of Wisdom I will gain immortality; I will live forever in the memory of those who come after me.

Chapter 8.8:14: I will hold power over nations and peoples;

Chapter 8.8:15: dreaded tyrants will be seized with fear at the mention of my name. I will be famous, as a good king and as a brave soldier.

Chapter 8.8:16: When I come home to Wisdom, I will find contentment because there is no conflict or pain in living with her, only happiness and joy.

Chapter 8.8:17: And so I thought it over: to be wedded to Wisdom is to live forever,

Chapter 8.8:18: to love her is to be perfectly happy, to do her work is to be rich beyond measure, to share her company is to have sound judgment, to converse with her is to be honored. Then I was determined to take Wisdom as my bride.

Chapter 8.8:19: I had a pleasant personality even as a child. I had been fortunate enough to receive a good soul, or rather, I was given a sound body to live in because I was already good.

Chapter 8.8:20: Still, I realized that I would never receive Wisdom unless God gave her to me—and knowing that only God could give her to me was itself a sign of understanding. So I prayed, begging the Lord with all my heart:

Chapter 9.9:1: God of my ancestors, merciful Lord, by your word you created everything.

Chapter 9.9:2: By your Wisdom you made us humans to rule all creation,

Chapter 9.9:3: to govern the world with holiness and righteousness, to administer justice with integrity.

Chapter 9.9:4: Give me the Wisdom that sits beside your throne; give me a place among your children.

Chapter 9.9:5: I am your slave, as was my mother before me. I am only human. I am not strong, and my life will be short. I have little understanding of the Law or of how to apply it.

Chapter 9.9:6: Even if someone is perfect, he will be thought of as nothing without the Wisdom that comes from you.

Chapter 9.9:7: You chose me over everyone else to be the king of your own people, to judge your sons and daughters.

Chapter 9.9:8: You told me to build a temple on your sacred mountain, an altar in Jerusalem, the city you chose as your home. It is a copy of that temple in heaven, which you prepared at the beginning.

Chapter 9.9:9: Wisdom is with you and knows your actions; she was present when you made the world. She knows what pleases you, what is right and in accordance with your commands.

Chapter 9.9:10: Send her from the holy heavens, down from your glorious throne, so that she may work at my side, and I may learn what pleases you.

Chapter 9.9:11: She knows and understands everything, and will guide me intelligently in what I do. Her glory will protect me.

Chapter 9.9:12: Then I will judge your people fairly, and be worthy of my father's throne. My actions will be acceptable.

Chapter 9.9:13: Who can ever learn the will of God?

Chapter 9.9:14: Human reason is not adequate for the task, and our philosophies tend to mislead us,

Chapter 9.9:15: because our mortal bodies weigh our souls down. The body is a temporary structure made of earth, a burden to the active mind.

Chapter 9.9:16: All we can do is make guesses about things on earth; we must struggle to learn about things that are close to us. Who, then, can ever hope to understand heavenly things?

Chapter 9.9:17: No one has ever learned your will, unless you first gave him Wisdom, and sent your holy spirit down to him.

Chapter 9.9:18: In this way people on earth have been set on the right path, have learned what pleases you, and have been kept safe by Wisdom.

Chapter 10.10:1: Wisdom protected the father of the world, the first man that was ever formed, when he alone had been created. She saved him from his own sinful act

Chapter 10.10:2: and gave him the strength to master everything on earth.

Chapter 10.10:3: But there was an unrighteous man who abandoned Wisdom; he destroyed himself by killing his brother in a fit of anger.

Chapter 10.10:4: Because of that sin, the earth was flooded, but Wisdom saved it again. She guided a righteous man in his flimsy wooden boat.

Chapter 10.10:5: Once when the nations were frustrated in their wicked plans, Wisdom recognized a righteous man and kept him innocent in God's sight. She gave him strength to obey God's command in spite of his love for his son.

Chapter 10.10:6: Wisdom rescued a righteous man while ungodly people were dying. He escaped the flames that destroyed the Five Cities.

Chapter 10.10:7: You can still see the evidence of their wickedness. The land there is barren and smoking. The plants bear fruit that never ripens, and a pillar of salt stands as a monument to one who did not believe.

Chapter 10.10:8: The people of those cities ignored Wisdom and could not tell right from wrong. Not only that, but the remains of their cities still remind us of the foolish way they lived, so that their failure can never be forgotten.

Chapter 10.10:9: But Wisdom rescued her servants from the danger.

Chapter 10.10:10: A righteous man once had to escape from his brother's anger, and Wisdom guided him in the right way. She showed him God's kingdom and allowed him to know about holy things. She made him prosperous and successful in his work.

Chapter 10.10:11: When others were greedy for what he had, and wanted to take it away from him, Wisdom stood by him and made him rich.

Chapter 10.10:12: She protected him from his enemies who were waiting for a chance to attack him. She gave him victory in a hard fight, so that he might realize that nothing can make a person stronger than serving God.

Chapter 10.10:13: Once a righteous man was sold into slavery, but Wisdom did not abandon him. She kept him safe from sin. She went to prison with him

Chapter 10.10:14: and never left him until she had given him power over an empire and made him the ruler of people who had once oppressed him. She let it be known that a false accusation had been made against him, and she gave him eternal honor.

Chapter 10.10:15: Wisdom once rescued an innocent and holy people from a nation of oppressors.

Chapter 10.10:16: She entered the soul of one of God's servants and stood up to dreaded kings by performing miracles.

Chapter 10.10:17: She rewarded God's people for their hardships. She guided them along a miraculous journey. She gave them shade during the day and brilliant starlight at night.

Chapter 10.10:18: She led them through the deep waters of the Red Sea,

Chapter 10.10:19: but she drowned their enemies and washed their bodies up on the shore.

Chapter 10.10:20: And so the righteous looted the ungodly. They sang hymns to your holy name, O Lord; together they praised you for defending them.

Chapter 10.10:21: Wisdom gave speech to those who could not speak; she even caused babies to speak clearly.

Chapter 11.11:1: Wisdom brought success to the people of Israel through a holy prophet.

Chapter 11.11:2: They traveled across a desert where no one lived and camped in places where no human being had ever been.

Chapter 11.11:3: They stood up to their enemies and fought them off.

Chapter 11.11:4: When your people grew thirsty, they called to you, Lord, and you gave them water flowing out of solid rock.

Chapter 11.11:5: The disasters that punished the Egyptians saved your people when they were in trouble.

Chapter 19.19:6: The whole nature of the universe was changed at your command so that your people would not be harmed.

Chapter 19.19:7: They saw the cloud over their camp and dry land where water had been. There was a grass-covered plain between the stormy waves of the Red Sea, making it easy for them to cross over.

Chapter 19.19:8: All your people, under your protection, saw this miracle and went across.

Chapter 19.19:9: They pranced about like horses let out to pasture; they skipped about like lambs and praised you, Lord, for saving them.

Chapter 19.19:10: They still remembered what life had been like when they were slaves—how the earth bred gnats instead of cattle, how the river produced huge numbers of frogs instead of fish.

Chapter 19.19:11: Later, when they desperately wanted better food, quails came up from the sea to satisfy their hunger. The quail was a bird they had never seen before.

Chapter 19.19:13: But violent thunder gave warning of the punishment that was coming on those sinners. They suffered a well-deserved punishment for their great wickedness. No nation had ever hated strangers so bitterly.

Chapter 19.19:14: Other people had been known to refuse welcome to strangers who came to them, but these people made slaves of those who were their guests and who had shown them kindness.

Chapter 19.19:15: Every nation will be punished if it does not welcome foreigners,

Chapter 19.19:16: but these people, who had earlier welcomed the foreigners with happy celebrations and treated them as equals, later made them suffer cruelly.

Chapter 19.19:17: These people were also struck with blindness, like the men of Sodom who came to the door of that righteous man Lot. They found themselves in total darkness, as each one groped around to find his own door.

Chapter 19.19:18: On a harp each string keeps its own pitch, but each sound can be combined with others to make different melodies. That is how it was in those days, when the very elements entered into new combinations. Look at what happened!

Chapter 19.19:19: Land animals took to the water, and swimming creatures came up on the land.

Chapter 19.19:20: Fire burned even in water, which could not put it out.

Chapter 19.19:21: And yet the flames could not burn the flesh of the perishable creatures walking in them and did not melt that heavenly food that would ordinarily have melted like frost.

Chapter 19.19:22: Lord, you have made your people great—glorious in all respects. You have never neglected them. You have given them help, always, everywhere.
